qas.question: Which two areas in the British Isles hasn't experienced a large population growth in the last one hundred years?
How does Ireland's population compare to the rest of the British Isles?

answers.text: less than one tenth of the population of the British Isles

qas.question: How long did the Great Irish Famine cause a population decline in Ireland?
How large is the Irish diaspora that was caused by the Great Irish Famine?

answers.text: fifteen times the current population of the island

qas.question: The population in England declined fast during which centuries?
During the 17th and 18th centuries, what happened to the population in England?
The population in Scotland and what other country have increased rapidly?
The population of Scotland has experienced a significant change in every year since when?
The Great British Famine caused the population of Ireland to fall below one tenth of the population of?

context: The population of England <b5_0>rose rapidly<b5_0/> during the <b4_0>19th and 20th centuries<b4_0/> whereas the populations of <a0_0>Scotland and <b6_0>Wales<b6_0/><a0_0/> have shown little increase during the 20th century, with the population of Scotland remaining unchanged since <b7_0>1951<b7_0/>. Ireland for most of its history comprised a population proportionate to its land area (about one third of the total population). However, since the Great Irish Famine, the population of Ireland has fallen to <a1_0>less than one tenth of the population of <b8_0>the British Isles<b8_0/><a1_0/>. The famine, which caused a <a2_0>century-long population decline<a2_0/>, drastically reduced the Irish population and permanently altered the demographic make-up of the British Isles. On a global scale, this disaster led to the creation of an Irish diaspora that numbers <a3_0>fifteen times the current population of the island<a3_0/>.
